@[Geoffroy], before we make a final decision on whether to create a single database for the pedigree of all different horse types or to use a common database, I have the following questions:
• The most crucial question is: to what extent would the system's speed be affected by having separate pedigree databases?
• Each horse type (warmbloods, PRE, thoroughbreds) may or may not consist of specific breeds. For instance, warmbloods include Hanoverians, Oldenburgs, Westphalians, etc. PRE and thoroughbreds, however, are generally considered a single breed.
Therefore, if we opt for a single pedigree database, we would need to segregate the horses by type in the pedigree. This means if a user enters a warmblood, they should not find PRE or thoroughbreds from which to search for their horse in the pedigree.
However, there are exceptions, like with ponies, where about 0.5% of the horses in the pedigree might be warmbloods.
Similarly, in warmbloods, there might be about 0.1% thoroughbreds.
And in PRE horses, there might occasionally be a warmblood in the pedigree.
Despite these nuances, horses should be categorized in the pedigree database by type: warmblood, pony, PRE, thoroughbred, or western horse, and then associated with their specific breed under these categories.
Given these circumstances, what would you suggest as the best solution for HORSE24?
Also, if we now create a platform called LIVESTOCK24, it would be a platform where cows, sheep, pigs, and goats are offered. However, these animal types have nothing in common. There could be sub-breeds of cows or sheep, but a cow and a pig share nothing in their pedigree.
We need to consider what would be the best solution for us in this scenario.

Hi @[Romina True]
As designed in DB, we have a table (Product Person) for Breeders and Owners…, informations.

This table is not linked directly to Users table. We will store the person informations in That table. Then if there is already a user with that informations, we will link that user account with the person (Breeder or Owner or whatever else).  It is thought like that because Owner, or Breeder or veterinary for example may not have yet a user account in our system.

Later if that person would like to register we can then link the user account to it.

About The document screenshot you sent we can grab informations from the columns and insert into person table. But to do so we will require that the document always follow a known structure. This way in code we will know that this column contains firstname follow by lastname for example.

@[Eric AKPLA] It is very strange to me. The issue is with the SiteResource type. I checked the scramble documentation in detail, and normally scramble should infer the type from the SiteResource class using the Site model which is referenced using `@mixin \Domains\Site\Models\Site` However, it's not working, and it's setting the type to string instead of bool.
<https://scramble.dedoc.co/usage/response>
In the end I solved it by adding phpdoc on the resource. I guess it's the best we can do for now. Anyway we should do this for JSON objects which can't be type inferred from the database model.
@[Eric AKPLA] Can you please comment?

You don't know either why the type inference isn't working, right? :sweat_smile:

The package rely on doctrine/dbal package to infer attribute type from DB. Laravel 11 no more depends on that package. So by installing it, it should be enough to infer the types but it does not work as installed it and nothing happened. So i don’t really know why it can not detect the types
Got you. Then I guess your way of phpdoc is the best way.

I’ve found why it could not detect the types. In the source code of the library it uses @mixin to find the models and prepend “\” to the model path. the model paths already exists with \ prepended.

Also the package does not implement type check for ‘whenHas’ method. that is why it could not detect the types.

But now i’m adding the phpdocs and it works. maybe later i can add an extension so it can support it

I’m thinking about it. but so far just by looking at the screenshot the core of this is part of the realtime service. When a user is online, it is known by the realtime because at the moment a user is on the page it initialize a connection to realtime and the service can know if the user has logged in or not.

The components that need information about the user can send a request (websocket) to the realtime to check if user is online or gather any other realtime informations.

Sending realtime messages like chat, notifications can be done by the realtime. Or another messaging canal can also be used.

I think other parts that need realtime  in admin will be same concept. It is also possible to delegate handling Admin realtime informations handling to another service. but that service have to communicate to realtime service to gather informations needed.

Hi @[Geoffroy] @[Arnaud] @[Pavlove BIOKOU] do you know if it's possible to implement validation routes for forms in addition to submission routes? I'm asking because I think it'd be nice to show server errors on inputs before user presses submit.

by sending a request on each input from the user ?
I think for example when user clicks out of a particular input, so we know they are done with this input
It's just something I'm wondering. Looking over the fields, I guess most can be validated on client side.
in this case you want that for each input we create a route ?
The theory would be like: `GET /api/sites/validate?key="country"&value="DE"`

On the client, all input fields have a unique path. For example path can be `<http://description.de|description.de>` or `aliases.0.rootDomain` . This comes from vee-validate. I don't know how it is on the server.
I think that it’s better to validate the whole form on submit.
For example, if a user fills in 80% of the form and then decides not to validate it any more and goes elsewhere, we would have made all these requests to the server unnecessarily.
That is fine, I was just wondering.
Well, I don't think the cost of the requests is an issue :sweat_smile: Most users don't edit forms all the time, 99% of our traffic is people just looking
To me the question seems the cost of development. It seems it is complex, and it is probably rare that it makes sense to validate a single field.
we can create the routes, but for me it’s not a really good approach.
for sure we will have to make validation like what you are saying but for some inputs in particular
I am working right now on the base of the form logic on the client, so I want to make sure to consider all options. It is starting to look very good and clean what I have. :smile:
ok good to hear :grinning:
But for the form, let’s validate the whole form on submit

The approach I use will allow us to write code to control in detail how the form is related to the API routes. So you will have maximum flexibility on the server API, while we can make it look as Simon wants on the client.

@[Romina True], In database, an auction can contain products from different categories.
The workflow here is that,
• admin create a Product ( the product will have every information set, based the  Category he belong to)
• admin then create a lot. In the lot, he will choose a Product, fill the pricing fields, choose the auction, setup lot order, lot number...
• admin can define an auction terms per ProductCategory
So it is all about creating a product independently from an auction, and then create a Lot which will have a product and belong to an auction.

Hi @[Christian Bielert], i hope you are fine.
I created this <https://sporthorses24.com/developers/katon/-/merge_requests/278|Merge request> that serve as a skeleton for organizing our models in the Nuxt App to be aligned with Resource responses that API will send.

You will notice that i did not touched the models folder in resources. it is just to not break what is done so far.
We want to move Validations schema into models because their belongs to validating data from forms that will be sent to backend api.
The models will no more be used just as type but will represent the instance of entity in the application. When fetching data from API the model will be used to create instance of the each record. it will parse columns into their corresponding object representation. As example dates as string in json can be parsed into Date, or Moment, etc…

When it comes to send form data to api, the model instance will be used to serialized the data in the format needed by the api.
So any manipulation of data in forms will operate on model instances.

If needed we can make a call to discuss about it

@[Eric AKPLA] For the new system, I think it will be good if we can notify the infrastructure about upcoming bidup. For example to apply different autoscaling behavior or instance size ahead of bidup. This will help to reduce cost during normal times, while having better safety during bidup. I guess the best place to send the notification will be from Laravel, but not sure.

Auction bidup times are known in advance so that the start can be anticipate using a cron task. as in the current system Laravel has schedule job (task) system that can be configured as a cron job. That is why 1mn before bidup starts we send Lots to bidup scheduler…

We can use it in same way for scaling. But in my opinion, as we may have different auctions same day but for different hours,  it may not be good to scale by bidup auctions that is about to start. But i think it is good to let the system scale by charge…

I observed many auctions on netdata and ASG, and the issue is that auto scaling doesn't work well for bidup. As there may be 2x or 3x traffic in 1-2 minutes as bidup is about to happen. Auto scaling can't deal with this well as it takes several minutes for new instances to scale up. This is why using "charge" to scale alone is not good.

Also DDoS will usually be around time of bidup. So during bidup we should have higher amount of servers compared to load than during other times. It's a good way to be safe from DDoS while not paying too much at other times.

@[Romina True] What is the purpose of creating permission groups from admin?

I'm asking because we should be sure everything we create has a good purpose. Not to create things because we think it may be needed, and then in practice it's less useful than we thought. This is why we should aim to build an "MVP" or minimum viable product, and then to add things as we really see they are needed when we can really play with the system.

The idea behind the permission groups is to avoid setting hundreds of single permissions to a role directly. By grouping them according to their functionalities like e.g. editing or deleting it makes it much easier to assign them to a role and we make sure that we do not forget a single permission somewhere or loose overview

@[Arnaud] I have experimented many ideas. It just makes the structure of the components much easier, because we don't need many props and events. Especially when we have lists of components with `v-for`, it is easier in my experiments to access the store directly, instead of passing events through many components.

In a traditional design like we have on running system, we can just use forms to take care of the communication between components. But because of the complex design with each area having its own "edit" button, a store is the best solution.

Ok. I know it's not the point here but it's important to think about it: how to handle the validation error messages from the backend in this case. Will we push them in the store si they will be displayed under the fields?

Yes, exactly. Validation errors is part of the reason to use a store. If not using a store, we would need an errors object that gets passed to every single component in the form. It would be a lot of props just for this.
With the store it is more easy to put the validation errors directly as part of the store.
Although to be honest, I'm not sure validation errors were really considered in the UX design.

For example, when you click publish here. How would the validation errors be displayed? It is not in a mode where there are fields to display the errors on the fields. So would it have to open the form on the part where the error happens? It's unclear.

Yes, as I haven't gotten the API definition from you yet. But it will be a simple mapping from the result of the API call to the store.
ok got you

Another reason to use the store, is that it is much easier to work with now thanks to ChatGPT. So for example, once we have the API spec, we can give the spec and the store to ChatGPT, and ask it to create a mapping function. Here the way a store is defined in a single file is a big advantage.
And pinia is also much less code to write than stores I used in the past, like ngrx :sweat_smile: Events can be created just as functions, you don't need to create types for each event

Hi @[Simon Kohlenbrenner] @[Eric AKPLA] regarding authentication, I think we should have some discussion. In particular for bidding. As with the normal auth token method of authentication, there are some risks. For example:
1. User could leave computer unlocked and someone else would bid for them
2. User's browser could be hacked and have auth token stolen, then the hacker can bid for them
There are ways involving cryptography and 2FA to make this more secure, so we should consider this possibility when designing our authenticaiton system from scratch. 2FA can also be a good option for confirming dangerous operations on admin.

<!channel> Here are my requirements for the Laravel project so far. It's still a work in progress. We will probably have to have more discussions later, this is just so you can know the idea.

```Requirements:
- It must be possible to install the project on any machine with a single command (e.g. using docker)
- Server route latency and server resource usage (php CPU, database accesses) must be optimized
- As many users will see exactly the same thing (e.g. all users who go on an auction page will see the same data), consider a good caching approach
- Server should be scalable to many users
- Automated tests for the server (including stress tests)
- It must be possible to write full realtime tests of auctions (including concurrent bids from different users etc.)
- Handling of different product types (think about abstractions)
- Avoid code duplication```

I’d suggest we simplify things a little.

Let’s create tailwind component layers and use them.
For example, for the button component, we can create bootstrap-style classes: `.btn`, `.btn-sm,` `.btn-lg`, `.btn-primary`, `.btn-success`, .`btn-flat` etc... then we can use them in the components. I gave the example of the button but we can have classes for everything else.
I don't really understand. Isn't it better to have the appearance of a button modular in the Button.vue than to have the styles for all components in one huge css file?
It will still modular and we actually don’t need to have only one huge css file. Good organization would even suggest having one css file per component, for example button.css, card.css etc...
:sweat_smile:
It seems to be a very roundabout way of going back to just having <style scoped> just way more complicated and with more files...
In this case I would say we will just use <style scoped> instead
Having separate .css files is bad in my opinion, as it encourages too large components.

Nevermind the way you did is actually good according to the advice in their doc
<https://tailwindcss.com/docs/reusing-styles#extracting-classes-with-apply>

But according to this what was done in @[Arnaud]’s branch is not good
@[Pavlove BIOKOU] Ok got you. Yes I discussed this with Arnaud
Normally we should not do it this way, but I decided for global design system it is the best way.

So it's only for stuff like this where we will use layers
<https://xd.adobe.com/view/96eebebd-2b29-4ccf-bd71-d671432e0391-c3bd/screen/a6a00816-b654-4a98-a40b-94deb9e1bb9a/specs/>
ok

In my understanding the general approach with tailwind is the following:
1. Many times, we can use components to define the styling of common components. For example, in the .btn example, where we know all buttons will have the same tailwind classes, we can just create Button.vue instead
2. But in some rare cases like h1, general spacing rules, etc. it's not possible to define a vue component just for this case. Then we need to use layers
I think this is the rule we can go by. We should put it in our docs, too
